I was trying to help another team with their swerve setup, and so clicked around awhile, discovering that their Java code all ended in CTRE swerve JNI. is the C++ part of this available somewhere I could poke at it?

The new C++ based swerve code isn’t public, but you can take a look at the LegacySwerveDrivetrain and other LegacySwerve classes from the original Java version in order to get a fairly decent understanding of the C++ code does.

it’s not public at all? really?

there must be some misunderstanding here.

@bhall-ctre ?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-20T17:33:45.578Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":122,"readers_count":121,"score":44.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":492448,"topic_slug":"ctre-swerve-source-code","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/ctre-swerve-source-code/492448/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3534699,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-20T20:49:17.270Z","cooked":"

The C++ implementations of all SwerveRequest types are public, as are a few of the native SwerveDrivetrain and SwerveModule method implementations. However, the remaining methods are in the .cpp files for several reasons (such as compilation time for our C++ users), and only header files (.hpp or .h) are publicly visible.

With that said, there aren’t too many changes in those method implementations compared to those in LegacySwerveDrivetrain or LegacySwerveModule, so you can look at those implementations to get an idea of how the C++ versions work. Some of the swerve requests are also implemented in Java, as is applying all of the device configs.

bhall-ctre:

The C++ implementations of all SwerveRequest types are public, as are a few of the native SwerveDrivetrain and SwerveModule method implementations. However, the remaining methods are in the .cpp files for several reasons (such as compilation time for our C++ users), and only header files (.hpp or .h) are publicly visible.

What’s the difference between the legacy swerve code and the current code? Is the legacy code still usable?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-21T03:21:09.725Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":16.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":492448,"topic_slug":"ctre-swerve-source-code","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61554,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 5895"},"post_url":"/t/ctre-swerve-source-code/492448/5","custom_user_title":"FRC 5895","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3535042,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-21T03:33:13.447Z","cooked":"

The legacy swerve code is still usable, but we recommend that most teams use the new API instead.

The legacy code is written entirely in Java, which makes it subject to timing issues from GC as well as a much higher GC pressure (an average team would see a GC event every 1.5 seconds). We are also not developing any new features for the legacy API; the newer API has a few like the ApplyFieldSpeeds request or support for wheel force feedforward vectors. The common C++ implementation of the new API also lets us support swerve in all three official FRC languages.

The legacy API also only supports using Talon FX and CANcoder, whereas the new API also supports Talon FXS and CANdi.

@bhall-ctre thanks for getting back to me. I looked through the stuff you pointed out, but I don’t think it would be very helpful to the students.

I hope you guys will make all your code public soon. It would help students understand more about the topics of kinematics, dynamics, and control in the systems they’re building. The more they can see and experiment with (i.e. modify the code, try things out), the better the outcomes for them. As it is, CTRE is a growing black box.
